meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrew Teixeira (WPI)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I've got a slightly different pathway to bring up I guess. Anyone have any ideas on NOx or NOx chemistry or if that could be related? Somebody mentioned the nitrogen-nitrogen bond is very stable, hard to break, while the nitrogen-oxygen bond is a little bit easier. And if we're talking about CO2, I mean technically beyond CO2, but can CO2 be an oxidant to oxidize dinitrogen to form NOx which then we can process downstream through other means? I know there's a lot of technology in NOx reduction out there already. So, just a thought to put out there.
meeting_annotations.other: Andrew introduces a new topic (NOx chemistry) to the discussion after a period of silence.

meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess on the flip side I was also interested in an electrochemical analog of reduction of NOx having done some a little bit of zeolite work on NOx SCR via ammonia. meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I guess my hope was we have dry reforming of methane where we could use CO2 as an oxidant. So I was imagining can we both kill two birds with one stone, use CO2 and get a pathway to activate nitrogen.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Haotian Wang
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I think that's a very interesting idea if we can use carbon dioxide to oxidize nitrogen. I never saw that before.
